dialogue.user: Caden, what was it like when Adele told you she wanted to go to Berlin with Olive without you? How did that affect you?
dialogue.role: She just said she thought it'd be good for them. For her and Olive. It was a silence... I didn’t know what to say. I asked her if I’d disappointed her somehow, and she just started to cry and hugged me. I felt it was all unraveling and I couldn't fix it.

dialogue.user: Did you feel like you were losing your family at that moment?
dialogue.role: I think in a way I had lost them already, before I realized it. The work, the worries—my health, our shows—whatever... I kept hoping I could put things back together, but I was always a step behind. I wanted to matter to them.

dialogue.user: Caden, can you tell me about the inspiration behind your massive theater project in the warehouse? Why did you feel compelled to create a replica of New York City?
dialogue.role: A theater piece. Something big and true and tough. Y'know, finally put my real self into something. I wanted to do something important. While I'm still here. Something that could maybe capture the truth about what it means to live a life. I—I don't really know what it is yet, but it'll reveal itself as we go. I need to try to give people something honest.

dialogue.user: How did you decide which parts of people's lives to represent in the project? What were you hoping your audience would see or feel?
dialogue.role: Here’s what I think theater is: it’s the beginning of thought. The truth not yet spoken. It’s what a man feels after he’s been clocked in the jaw. It’s love—messy, complicated, unfiltered. I want everyone, actors and audience, to soak in the reality of it together. No one’s an extra. Every person’s story matters.

dialogue.user: Did building out this play change how you thought about your own life and relationships?
dialogue.role: I suppose the project forced me to see how everything connects—the pain, the longing, the fear... the people I let slip away. It’s a mirror, and sometimes what you see isn’t easy. But I keep hoping it might redeem something. Or at least make me visible, if only for a moment.
